captions.text:
Wassup Droogie? This week gettin’ a taste
of the ol ultra-violent with A Clockwork Orange
by Anthony Burgess.

England sho as hell seen better days. Cuz
up in this crooked-ass future, the government

got errybody by the nuts and young thugz rule
the streets doin violent deeds on the reg.

And there ain’t no gang rollin rougher than
Alex and his droogies Dim, Georgie, and Pete.

One night after sippin sumodat crunk-stuff
at the Korova Milk Bar, Alex and his boys

hit the streets to get their fix of sweet
violence. After whoopin up some strangers,

lootin’ a store and boosting a car, Alex
and da crew swang through the boonies when

they stop a cottage, mask up, bust in, BRUTALIZE
da husband and rape his woman while he WATCH.

Damn, B. This is some f***** up sh*t right
hurr.

Later, dem Droogies start flexin like they
be questioning Alex’s authority. But when

Alex whips out his shank, he puts dem bitches
back in their place. Cold blooded.

That night they decide to step up their game
by robbin some rich old hag’s crib. Alex

sneak in and knock dat bitch out, but not
before the 5- 0 be closin’ in.

Just as Alex bout to bail, Dim pops Alex in
his grill, leaving him to get GOT by the fuzz.

Now 15-yr old Alex got his ass tossed in the
clink.

After Alex smacks up one his cellmates real
good, he gets picked to be a lab rat for some

shit called The Ludovico Technique. Basically,
a bunch of government scientists pump his
ass with drugs, make him watch videos of real messed up sh*t, and condition him to get sick

as a dog whenever he think of something violent
or sexual. Thing is, these videos sometimes

bumpin classical music, which be one of the
only things that mean a damn thing to him.

Now he can’t listen to his jam without losin
his yarbles. Since he “rehabilitated,”
Alex gets released to the outside.

While Alex lurkin round da streets, he keeps
gettin his ass kicked by peeps who recognize
him from his gang-bangin days. Just when sh*t’s gettin rough, the law breaks up the scuffle.

But turns out, one of these badge-wavin crackas
is DIM. Da hell?!
After gettin straight F***** up by some back then hustlaz, Alex stumbles to a cottage beggin

fo help. Turns out, Alex now chillin with
the same brutha whose ass he beat and whose

wife he raped. Luckily, he don’t recognize
Alex at first. Instead, he just wanna use

Alex as a poster boy for his posse of anti-government
blowhards. But just like the government, they

just gonna put the hurt on Alex for they own
ends. So they lock him up in a room, start

bangin some classical music, and Alex try
to snuff it.

But since dat was a little bitch fall, Alex
ends up aight. Actually he better than aight.

He been cured of the Ludovico Technique. After
a while, Alex gets to thinkin, realize how

empty his life be, and decide to stop thuggin
ultra violent, and make himself a one lady
man. Man this ending sucks. GO WATCH THE MOVIE!

Now yo bitch-ass might be thinkin: Da hell
this got to do with oranges? Well peep this,

sucka- tha book’s title spittin game bout
tryna take something organic, like an orange,

and tryna make it work like a machine- which
is exactly what errybody tryin to do to Alex,

not just the scientists. And if Alex cayn’t
choose between good and evil, then he ain’t
a human being- he’s just a clockwork orange.

Matter of fact, Alex’s name got a built
in “f*** you” to all those people tellin
him how he gotta roll. See, da name Alexander mean “defender of man.” And in Alex’s

case, he’s fighting for humanity’s right
to choose even if they choosin to do some
twisted things.

Look, even though the state tryin to do some
good by usin the jacked up Ludovico Technique,

they ain’t just riddin the world of evil.
They also killin the good. Like one of dem
goverment puppets say-

“Delimitation is always difficult. The world
is one, life is one. The sweetest and most
heavenly of activities partake in some measure of violence – the act of love, for instance;
music, for instance.”

See problem is cultures always thinkin in
black and white. Something’s either good

or its evil. But on the real, it’s never
that simple. Nothing’s ever completely good
or completely evil.
But no matter how many damn times some ballin’ artist or philosopher spit dat truth, we just
can’t seem to understand it. Humanity gonna think they got errything all figured out,
only to bone up and do it over and over again. Like clockwork, playa.
So start yo re-education by hittin dat subscribe button, padna. Viddy- well my literary OGs.

title: A Clockwork Orange - Thug Notes Summary & Analysis

comments.text: " Walking, talking STEREOTYPE "﻿
comments.author: communistjesus

comments.text:
I...really like this. But I disagree about the ending. It's pretty much the 
pinnacle of Anthony Burgess's point which is that self reformation is the 
ultimate firm of free will. As opposed to the movie which suggests that one 
can never change and implies that people are born good and evil. Sure it's 
not very exciting as an ending but it does give the notion of Alex's future 
of creation. Which is open to anything the imagination of the reader can 
conjure up.﻿
comments.author: Vinny Raptor

comments.text:
The droogies viddied their brutal slang real horror show cause it brutally 
rendered Alex and his friends social pathology.  The book made its points 
and also is meant as a satire on the distortions of the mind.  That being 
said, it's absolutely true that there's never absolutes.  The reason that 
so many people can't understand this, is due to religious ideologies which 
separates things in forms of light and dark.  Christianity or any branch 
there of, is the most responsible for setting things in black and white. 
 Almost everyone on the planet has been, still is, and will continue to be 
religious in their beliefs in some way, shape, or form, so yeah, the 
beliefs of religion is directly responsible for the lack of understanding 
of other matters in the equation.﻿

comments.author: Ethan Bensinger

comments.text:
The problem with the symbolism of the Ludovico Technique is that its flaws 
seem extremely minor compared to the alternative presented. Alex and his 
gang start off as horrible people and what they do to their victims is far 
more significant than one persons ability to enjoy classical music or 
sexuality.
That's why I think the ending is necessary: when Alex was under the 
techniques influence, he didn't have a chance of redemption because he 
wasn't free and he also didn't have any way to fight back when the 
consequences of his guilt haunted him. The good that was prevented by 
Ludovico Technique wasn't the enjoyment of classical music or sexuality - 
it was the choice to be a good person.﻿
comments.author: Alex Bermann

comments.text:
Very nicely done.  I especially enjoyed your take on "the doubleness of the

comments.author: Art Koenig

comments.text:
I didn't like either ending. I didn't like the book ending because I didn't 
think a scumbag like Alex deserved to settle down and have a family. He's a 
rapist and a murderer, what he deserves is to suffer for his actions. When 
you commit abhorrent crimes, your freedom is forfeit, and the egregious 
nature of his crimes warrant the forfeiture of his freedom for the rest of 
his life.

I didn't like the movie ending for the same reason. Whether he became good 
or not does not change the fact that he's indulging in his desires when 
they should be forfeit as punishment for his abhorrent crimes.﻿
comments.author: EnigmaHood

comments.text:
+wendy diaz Well yeah, actually Burgees was a victim of violence. I believe 
the rape scene was based on a real life event that happened in his family's 
life.

But he does try to tell us that taking away a person's freewill is wrong. 
I'm not so sure I agree with that. Putting someone in prison also takes 
away their freewill and we do that all the time.
comments.author: EnigmaHood

comments.text:
+EnigmaHood I see your point. Burgees wasn't trying to praise violence in 
anyway. He was after this idea of the choice between picking good or bad is 
what makes human.

The only thing missing to me is explanation of the use of Russian (or just 
slavic) words in the book and the movie. They just randomly say stuff in 
Russian and never explain it! Like the bar's called Korova (which is the 
Russian for cow), they say "devochka" sometimes (girl in Russian) etc.

Probably the author tried to create a new slang just for this book or 
something but it's really worth looking into :)﻿

comments.text:
Burgess created a "teenage" language for the youths in the book to use so 
he called it Nadsat :) it's a mix of Russian, old English, and rhyming 
words, and some of the ways he incorporates it are genius. Like khorosho 
(good or well) as "horrowshow" or golova (head) into "gulliver"

comments.text:
Burgess also claimed the title was a pun on the Malay word for man, 
"orang." Thus, a clockwork orang, a machine-man. It's the same point, 
juxtaposing the natural and chaotic with the artificial and regimented, 
just a different path to that conclusion. ﻿

comments.author: Quinton Doucet

comments.text:
In my opinion, the book ending sucks, not because he gets married and has a 
family (although I hate the family=redemption association. You can have a 
family and still be an asshole) but because he doesn't change at all. He 
gets bored, and the ultra-violence is treated as  a teen phase he 
eventually grows out of, like nose piercing or something. He basically 
thinks that, now that he's old (he's 18. Dystopian future indeed), he might 
as well settle down and have kid, whom he'll try to educate though he knows 
that he'll probably grow up to be a thug just like he was, and then again 
until the end of time, like a sort of twisted Circle of Life. 
What baffles me is that the author really thought that this was a happy 
ending, but really, it implies that everyone you've met or will meet might 
have been a rapist once, and then they just got bored. ﻿
comments.author: Niniane17

comments.text:
+Niniane17 I understand your opinion but for me I feel as if you can read 
the book deeper than just that. I did see Alex change at the end. We can 
obviously see in the book that violence is associated with immaturity and 
it's not the fact that he's 18 or bored that makes him want to have a son. 
As Alex is maturing he realizes he doesn't need to use violence as an 
affirmation of his freewill anymore. And at the end Alex says how as long 
as God keeps spinning the earth there will always be evil, which Burgees 
wasn't trying to imply that everyone will be rapist, he was going after 
this idea that sin is inevitable and it takes true free will to pick 
goodness. Which is the reason why Alex decides to ultimately choose "good."
comments.author: wendy diaz

comments.text:
+Vinny Raptor But that's the thing: it doesn't come from "free will" at 
all. One day he just finds out that he doesn't like his life anymore, so he 
stops.  If he had said something like "Today I will not rape anymore, even 
thought I want to", maybe I would have accepted it. But like that, it comes 
off as considering evil like an external force that you have to endure 
until it just fades away, and the individual's free will has nothing to do 
with it.
comments.author: Niniane17

comments.text:
Maybe to you because that's what you focus on the most but I look to Alex's 
future and believe that his past makes the ending all the more beautiful. 
Not that I'm saying it's OK to be a rapist because that's never OK but it 
makes me more appreciative that overcomes his own darkness. Which pretty 
much empowers the while point of Anthony Burgess's message of the story, 
and that being that self reformation is the ultimate free will.
comments.author: Vinny Raptor

comments.text:
+Niniane17 I think the ending of the novel was meant to present some kind 
of irony in the fact that the authorities tried as hard as they could to 
change and Alex and make him a better person when, in the end, Alex simply 
learnt to change by himself with time.
comments.author: CupidStunt

comments.author: Cloak and Dagger

comments.text:
+Niniane17 There were 2 versions. American version ending very much like 
Kubrick's, in that Alex was back to his old self. Some viewers are confused 
on the abstract visual imagery. Essentially, it's a literal "marriage" of 
the elite political and the orgy of working class youth -- you can do 
whatever you want just as long as it serves our political and financial 
interests. Hence the NRA
